26 Oct 2011

The Ontario Lakes Project: Allumette Lake

By in category

Champlain with Interpreter and Wendat; J. D. Kelly

Allumette Lake isn’t just any lake along the Ottawa River. This little body of water was the site of a ‘majah’ scandal in 1613 where people were drowning in a sea of lies.

Explorer Nicholas de Vignau travelled with an Algonquin chief named Tessouat. The two stopped at Allumet Lake where Tessouat told Vignau not to travel any further north because the tribes who resided there were “evil sorcerers.” Tessouat lied to Vignau (which he was in the habit of doing) to block travel north so he and his tribe could maintain control over trade with Quebec.
Vignau went back to New France (Quebec) falsely boasting that he’d travelled north and found the Northwest Passage (Hudson’s Bay). In 1613 Samuel de Champlain followed Vignau back to the site and discovered that Vignau was a boldfaced lier.  Champlain and Vignau encountered Algonquin chief Tessouat at Allumet Island where Champlain told Tessouat of Vignau’s claim.
Tessouat outed Vignau saying “If you visited those tribes, it was in your sleep.” In other words, in your dreams baby.
Vignau was never heard from again. Tessouat  apparently told Champlain: “Give him to us, and we promise you he will tell no more lies.” All that Champlain wrote in his diary was: “We left him in God’s keeping.”
Champlain gave up on finding the passage north and returned downstream.

Since ’98, we’ve helped a lot of interesting people do important things. We create relevant communications and useful experiences. Find out more.
